questions.text: 46-year-old man experiences syncope while getting out of bed. He has been feeling weak over the past week and complains of dyspnoea and chest discomfort. He believes that the symptoms are due to a respiratory infection 2 weeks ago, but he did not see a doctor at that time. His mother died of a stroke and his father suffered from recurrent myocardial infarctions. The patient eats a balanced diet and takes a daily multivitamin. His most recent total blood cholesterol level was 200 mg/dL. Electrocardiogram shows the following: The patient would most likely require which of the following treatments?

Identify the true statements: TxA2 has platelet aggregating and vasoconstricting effect Lipoxin B4 inhibits inhibit neutrophil chemotaxis and adhesion to endothelium. Il-1, Il-18, TNF are pyrogenic cytokines C3 can be activated in both common as well as alternative pathways T cells with a TCR composed of a γ and δ subunit are found associated with GI mucosa

72-year-old woman is brought to the office by her daughter for evaluation of leg swelling since 3 months. The patient has had fatigue and joint pains for the past several years, which she attributes to old age. The daughter states that the patient seems tired all the time, barely eats anything, and "is just not herself." The patient takes no medication and does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Blood pressure is 116/72 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min and regular. The lungs are clear on auscultation and heart sounds are normal. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Examination of the lower extremities reveals 3+ pitting edema. There are scattered ecchymoses, and hand examination findings are shown. Laboratory results are as follows: Creatinine: 0.9 mg/dL Calcium: 9.1 mg/dL Glucose: 94 mg/dL Allbumin: 2.8 g/dL Urinalysis reveals 4+ protein with no cells or casts. A renal biopsy of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

A 40-year-old man comes to the physician because of a two-week history of fatigue, lower extremity edema, and frothy urine. He has no history of serious illnesses. Physical examination shows symmetric pitting edema of lower extremities. Laboratory studies show a serum creatinine level of 1.1 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria. Electron microscopy of the specimen obtained from kidney biopsy shows dense deposits within glomerular basement membrane. Immunofluorescence microscopy is positive for C3, not immunoglobulins. Which of the following is the most likely pathophysiologic mechanism that explains this patient's condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway

questions.correct_answer: C. Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Persistent activation of the alternative complement pathway

questions.text: 53-year-old man comes to the physician complaining of increased urinary frequency for the past 4 weeks. He has no burning with urination, urgency, or difficulty initiating urination. He wakes up several times at night to urinate. His mouth feels dry all the time and he drinks fluids almost every hour to alleviate his thirst. The patient's medications include hydrochlorothiazide and amlodipine for hypertension. His sister was diagnosed with diabetes mellitus at a young age. His blood pressure is 120/76 mm Hg, pulse is 85/min, and respirations are 15/min. His body mass index is 32 kg/m². Laboratory results are as follows: Blood glucose-93 mg/dL Serum sodium-150 mEg:L Serum potassium-4.1 mEq/L Bicarbonate-24 mEq/L Blood urea nitrogen-21 mg/dL Serum creatinine-1.1 mg/dL Serum uric acid-10.1 mg/dL (N- 3.5-7.2 mg/dL) Serum osmolality-314 mOsm/kg (N- 275 to 295 mOsm/kg) Urine osmolality-124 mOsm/kg (N-500 - 800 mOsm/kg) Which of the following is most consistent with this patient's findings?

Identify the true statements: Rolapitant is the drug of choice for cisplatin induced intractable vomiting on the third day of treatment. Filgrastim is the drug of choice for chemotherapy induced thrombocytopenia Cephalosporins that do not require dose adjustment in renal failure because they are secreted in bile are ceftriaxone and cefoperazone. Denosumab can decrease bone resorption as well as increase bone formation

64-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of fever, chills, productive cough. The patient has a history of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Oxygen saturation is 94% on room air when lying on his right side but drops to 89% when he lies on his left. Dullness to percussion and bronchial breath sounds are present on the left side. Imaging is shown here. Which of the following pathophysiologic mechanisms in the left lung is most responsible for the drop in oxygen saturation after the change in position?

A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the back. Vital signs are normal. He is alert and oriented, with a Glasgow Coma Score of 15. Neurological examination demonstrates the absence of motor activity in all muscle groups of the right lower extremity as well as decreased muscle tone. Left leg motor function is normal. Right patellar reflex, Achilles reflex, and Babinski sign are absent. There is loss of light touch and proprioception below the right costal margin. Pinprick sensation is absent below the level of umbilicus on the left side. Which of the following is the most likely location of this patient's injury?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior spinal artery injury at T8

questions.correct_answer: D. Right spinal hemisection at T8
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Right spinal hemisection at T8

questions.text: A previously healthy 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department with lethargy and altered mental status. She was in her usual state of health until 5 days ago, when she developed a low-grade fever, malaise, headache, cough coryza, and a sore throat. The fever resolved with over-the-counter aspirin. The patient developed nausea, vomiting, and lethargy this morning. Examination shows a febrile, sleepy girl with hepatomegaly. There is no jaundice or splenomegaly. The patient is not oriented to person, place, or time. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin-14.2 g/L Platelets-180,000/mm³ Leukocytes-8,300/ mm³ Blood urea nitrogen-16 mg/dL Creatinine-0.6 mg/dL Glucose-72 mg/dL Total bilirubin-0.9 mg/dL Ammonia-94 mcg/dL (normal: <45 mcg/dL) Percutaneous liver biopsy would most likely reveal which of the following in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Cirrhosis and periportal eosinophilic inclusion bodies

questions.text: 32-year-old man is intubated and mechanically ventilated after an opioid drug overdose. He is sedated and passive. The ventilator triggers 14 breaths per minute, each delivering 500 mL of tidal volume at a peak flow rate of 60 L/min. An inspiratory hold is performed for 2 seconds following delivery of the tidal volume, and the airway pressure is measured to be 30 cm H20. The measured pressure most likely reflects which of the following?

55-year-old woman undergoes allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation from an HLA-matched, unrelated donor for treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. She received conditioning chemotherapy prior to the transplantation, and her immediate post-transplant course was uncomplicated. However, 3 weeks after the transplant, the patient develops worsening crampy abdominal pain and diarrhea. Medications include tacrolimus, prophylactic acyclovir, trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, and voriconazole. Physical examination shows generalized maculopapular rash. Stool testing for Clostridium difficile and PCR testing for cytomegalovirus are negative. Which of the following is the likely cause of this patient's diarrhea?
Hepcidin inhibits which of the following?
Match the following with the mode of cellular transport:

A 59-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to chest pain beginning 2 hours ago and profuse sweating 1 hour ago. He feels weak. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes and hypercholesterolemia. The patient's medications include metformin, glipizide, and simvastatin. Blood pressure is 165/98 mm Hg, pulse is 78/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. He appears mildly uncomfortable. Lungs are clear to auscultation. His ECG is shown. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Aspirin, cardiac enzyme levels, and observation in the intensive care unit

questions.correct_answer: C. Aspirin and immediate cardiac catheterization
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Aspirin and immediate cardiac catheterization

questions.text: 38-year-old woman comes to the office with a 3-week history of weight loss, nausea, abdominal pain, and postural dizziness. She travelled to Thailand 6 months ago and has felt fatigued since then. Medical history is notable for moderate persistent asthma treated with an inhaled beta-2 agonist and inhaled corticosteroid. Over the last 2 years, the patient has had several asthma exacerbations requiring oral prednisone. She also has hypothyroidism treated with levothyroxine. The patient is married and is a stay-at-home mother. Blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 96/min. Skin examination shows increased pigmentation at the palmar creases and mucous membranes. Initial laboratory testing shows mild hyponatremia and hyperkalaemia with normal renal function Complete blood count is normal, but differential shows moderate eosinophilia. Follow-up testing confirms a low 8AM serum cortisol. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's adrenal insufficiency?

options.label: D
options.text: Central adrenal insufficiency from glucocorticoid use

questions.text: Identify the true statements: Flow cytometry is the IOC for CLL MCL1, BCL-2, BCL-XL and PUMA are anti-apoptotic factors. Long-term hemodialysis patients with renal failure have accumulation of Aβ2-microglobulin. B cells express IgM and IgD antibodies at the same time due to somatic hypermutation CD16, CD56 and CD94 are NK cell markers.
All the following are signs of amitriptyline toxicity except: Coma and shock Hot dry skin Pinpoint pupil Hypotension

A 70-year-old male presents with progressive decline in his cardiac function and recued work capacity. He expired and on autopsy, the microscopic examination of the cardiac tissue revealed a yellow-brown pigment deposited in the cardiac cells. Which of the following is true about the location of the pigment present in this individual?
Identify the drug which has exclusive action shown in the graph without any other change in the action potential:

A 65-year-old patient with a history of coronary artery disease is prescribed clopidogrel (Plavix) and omeprazole (Prilosec) for concurrent use. Which of the following statements regarding this drug combination is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: The combination of clopidogrel and omeprazole is safe and does not require any monitoring.

options.label: B
options.text: Omeprazole may enhance the antiplatelet effects of clopidogrel, leading to improved cardiovascular outcomes.

options.label: C
options.text: Omeprazole inhibits the activity of CYP2C19, potentially reducing the effectiveness of clopidogrel and increasing the risk of cardiovascular events.

options.label: D
options.text: Clopidogrel increases the metabolism of omeprazole, leading to decreased therapeutic levels of omeprazole in the body.

questions.correct_answer: C. Omeprazole inhibits the activity of CYP2C19, potentially reducing the effectiveness of clopidogrel and increasing the risk of cardiovascular events.
questions.explanation: Ans. C. Omeprazole inhibits the activity of CYP2C19, potentially reducing the effectiveness of clopidogrel and increasing the risk of cardiovascular events.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to moderate pain in her lower back, hips, and knees for the past several weeks. She has no associated morning stiffness. The patient has end-stage renal disease due to diabetic nephropathy and has been on Hemodialysis for the past 2 years. Her other medical problems include type 1 diabeles mellitus diagnosed 20 years ago and sarcoidosis diagnosed 8 years ago. Physical examination shows no obvious bone or joint deformity, and she has full range of motion in all joints. Laboratory results are as follows: Sodium-136 mEq/L Potassium-3.9 mEq/L Bicarbonate-23 mEq/L Creatinine-3.1 mg/dL Calcium-7.9 mg/dL (N- 8.5 to 10.5 mg/dl) Phosphorus-6.1 mg/dL (N-2.8 to 4.5 mg/dL) Albumin-4.1 g/dL (N-3.4 to 5.4 g/dL) Which of the following is the most likely histopathological abnormality underlying this patient's current symptoms?

A 45-year-old male weighing 80kgs was started on a drug with Vd =10 L and exhibits first-order elimination kinetics. The rate of drug clearance is calculated to be 6.93 L/hr. It is determined that repeating the second dose when 75% of the drug is eliminated will minimize toxicity. Based on these research findings, which of the following is the most appropriate dosing interval for this drug?

A 58-year-old male patient presents to the hospital with a 6-week history of progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and a productive cough with greenish sputum. He has a past medical history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and has been treated multiple times for respiratory infections, though he mentions that they were never this prolonged or severe. On physical examination, you notice decreased breath sounds and crackles in the right lower lobe. A sputum culture identifies Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Which of the following antimicrobial agents is NOT effective against this organism?
Match the following scenarios with the best drug of choice:

A seventeen-year-old patient is brought to the emergency department having just ingested a large overdose of an antihistaminic drug. This drug is a weak base capable of entering most tissues including the brain. Which of the following statements is true:

options.label: A
options.text: Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NaHCO3, an alkalinizing agent.

options.label: B
options.text: Urinary excretion would be accelerated by the administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent.

options.label: C
options.text: More of the drug would be ionized at blood pH than at stomach pH.

options.label: D
options.text: Absorption of the drug would be faster from the stomach than from the small intestine.

questions.correct_answer: B. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by the administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent.
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Urinary excretion would be accelerated by administration of NH4Cl, an acidifying agent.

questions.text: An intraoperative frozen section has been sent by a surgeon to the pathology laboratory. A special stain has been applied by the pathologist as empty looking areas were found after routine staining resulting in inability to make any diagnosis. Identify the special stain used?

42-year-old woman comes to the office due to worsening double vision and gait unsteadiness. She states she had cramping abdominal pain and diarrhoea 2 weeks ago after an outdoor picnic which spontaneously resolved after 3 days. The double vision began 4 days ago and is persistent and progressive. She has had no fever, headache, neck pain, photophobia, or bowel or bladder dysfunction. On physical examination, she is fully alert and oriented with normal memory, speech, and language comprehension. There is mild ptosis of the right eye with weakness of the medial and upward gaze. Left eye movements are normal. Bilateral lower-extremity weakness with loss of deep tendon reflexes is present. Bilateral upper-extremity muscle strength, reflexes, and coordination are normal. Sensation to touch and pinprick is normal throughout. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's current condition?
Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below?

options.label: A
options.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin

options.label: B
options.text: A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

options.label: C
options.text: A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
questions.explanation: Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

questions.text: 31-year-old woman comes to the AIIMS OPD due to a 6.8-kg weight gain over the last few months. She has been unable to lose weight despite rigorous dieting and regular exercise. The patient also has experienced weakness and cannot lift weights hat she was able to lift before the onset of her symptoms. Her menstrual periods have been irregular for the last few months, and she has had increasing anxiety and insomnia for which she has started seeing a clinical psychologist. On examination, blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and pulse is 88/min and regular. Neurologic examination shows proximal muscle weakness. Dark terminal hair is present on the lower abdomen. Fasting laboratory results are as follows. Glucose-130 mg/dL Sodium-142 mEq/L Potassium-3.6 mEq/L Chloride-98 mEq/L Bicarbonate-28 mEq/L Calcium-9.2 mg/dL TSH-2.2 mlU/L (N-0.5 to 5.0 mIU/L) Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluating this patient's condition?
questions.correct_answer: B. Overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Overnight low-dose dexamethasone suppression test

questions.text: Match the following drugs with their specific side effects:

All of the following are true: Leptin acts via JAK-STAT signalling pathway Damage to the Zona Occludens can result in increased permeability in Vibrio cholera diarrhea Raised 2,3 BPG, Acidosis, HbF cause a right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve Macula densa is located at the Junction of thick ascending limb and DCT The organ with the least arteriovenous pressure difference is the kidney.

Identify the correct statements KEYNOTE-189 trial investigated NSCLC treatment using this drug that acts via pathway B. Drug acting via pathway B has a role in treatment of ca endometrium. Osimertinib is specifically used for treating NSCLC patients with T790M mutations and acts via pathway A. Ipilimumab is a medication used in the management and treatment of metastatic melanoma that acta via pathway C.

64-year-old man is evaluated for lower extremity edema and increasing abdominal discomfort. His past medica l history is significant for diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus and mitral valve repair su rgery 12 years ago. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 40 years. His blood pressure is 142/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 92/min and regular. Jugular venous pressure is estimated at 16 cm H2O (normal: <8cm H20). A mid-diastolic knock is heard on cardiac auscultation. Lungs are clear to auscultation. There is significant ascites and 4-+ lower extremity edema bilaterally. Chest x-ray reveals normal heart size, clear lung fields, and spotty calcifications along the left heart border. Echocardiogram shows enlarged atria, normal left ventricular wall thickness, normal right ventricular size, and left ventricular ejection fraction of 65%. There is mild mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

A 59-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to right leg swelling and pain for 2 days. The patient was started on hemodialysis 2 months ago for end-stage renal disease from diabetes mellitus. Duplex ultrasound shows a right popliteal vein thrombosis. The patient is started intravenous heparin infusion. On the third day of hospitalization, the right leg is more swollen and painful. Repeat ultrasound shows an extension of thrombus to the right femoral vein. Laboratory results are as follows: Hemoglobin-14.0 g/dL Platelets-50,000/mm³ Leukocytes-7,500/mm³ Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's worsening condition?

A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition?

Identify the true statements: Aminophylline acts as an adenosine receptor antagonist leading to diuresis Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant known to cause priapism Trofinetide, an analog of glycine-proline-glutamate (GPE), is used to treat cerebral palsy An orphan drug is a drug that is required for treatment or prevention of a rare disease
Which of the following is the correct sequence of cellular events of acute inflammation?

options.label: A
options.text: Rolling----Stable adhesion---Activation of integrins----Migration via endothelium

options.label: B
options.text: Rolling----Activation of Integrins----Stable Adhesion----Migration via endothelium

options.label: C
options.text: Stable adhesion---Rolling----Activation of integrins----Migration via endothelium

options.label: D
options.text: Activation of integrins----Migration via endothelium---Stable adhesion---Rolling

questions.correct_answer: B. Rolling----Activation of Integrins----Stable Adhesion----Migration via endothelium
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Rolling----Activation of Integrins----Stable Adhesion----Migration via endothelium

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of fever and joint pains. He is being treated with cephalexin for a skin infection. His urine has turned darker. His temperature is 38.5° C (101.3° F), blood pressure is 125/70 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 15/min. Examination shows a skin rash; examination otherwise shows no abnormalities. Urinalysis shows: 8 RBCs/HPF, 12 WBCs/HPF with white cell casts, eosinophiluria, and a mild degree of proteinuria. Laboratory studies show a BUN of 40 mg/dl and serum creatinine of 2.2 mg/dl. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: D
options.text: Get USG to rule out obstructive uropathy

questions.text: A 30-year-old man weighing 70 kg had a sodium level of 120 mEq, calculate sodium deficit?

46-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for elective cholecystectomy. He is started on intravenous fluids and antibiotics. Just before he is to go to an operating room, the patient complains of a sudden onset of chest tightness and light-headedness. His medical history is significant for anxiety, and he has had 2 previous visits to the emergency department for panic attacks. His blood pressure is 118/67 mm Hg. His electrocardiogram is shown here. Which of the following is the best initial step in treating this patient?

Identify the incorrect statement: Oral OCP-Increased total T4, normal TSH Elderly female on treatment for Hypothyroidism after starting HRT should increase her levothyroxine dose. Radioactive iodine is the treatment of choice for Graves ophthalmopathy. Elderly male admitted with acute flare of Ulcerative colitis showing low total T3, normal total T4 and normal TSH is due to abnormal thyroxine binding globulin levels.

70-year-old man comes to the OPD 4 weeks after experiencing an ischemic stroke. His medical history is significant for a long history of hypertension, diabetes, coronary artery disease, congestive heart failure, and atrial fibrillation. Vital signs are unremarkable. BMI is 23.8 kg/m². Cardiovascular examination reveals an irregularly irregular rhythm. The patient is right-handed. Only the right side of his face is shaved. Examination shows the following: Which of the following areas is most likely affected by the stroke in this patient?
Arrange the following steps of platelet changes in the correct sequence during hemostasis:
Pharmacologic equivalent of dobutamine is?

Which of the following statements is true about beta blockers: Carvedilol is the most widely used beta blocker. These are drug of choice in acute decompensated heart failure. Pindolol would be less likely to induce severe bradycardia in comparison to the other β-blockers. Sotalol can prolong the AP duration leading to torsade’s de pointes.
Identify the drug pharmacokinetics from the graphs:

options.label: D
options.text: Cannot be determined from the images

questions.text: 61-year-old male patient comes to the office complaining of involuntary shaking of his hands. It started on the right side but now his left handshakes as well. The shaking disappears with purposeful activity and worsens with emotional stress. He does not have a family history of tremors. Physical examination reveals a resting hand tremor with a frequency of 4-5 cycles/sec. There is some muscle rigidity of both arms. His gait and posture are normal. His mini mental status exam yields a score of 30/30. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
What is the treatment of choice for the condition that is the link between the following two images:
All the following are included in MDE (Myeloma defining Events) except:

60-year-old man comes to the office after he was found to have a "low blood count" when attempting to donate blood. The patient is in his usual state of health and feels well. He has no chronic medical problems but has been treated for pneumonia twice during the past year. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min. Physical examination reveals mucosal pallor. There are no enlarged lymph nodes. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The spleen tip is palpable 5 cm below the left costal margin; the liver is normal in size. Stool guaiac is negative. Complete blood count results are as follows: Hemoglobin-9.6 g/dL Platelets-130,000/mm³ Leukocytes-14,000/mm³ Peripheral blood smear shows predominant lymphocytes with features as seen in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

64-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diet-controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus comes to the office due to generalized malaise and palpitations for the past 2 weeks. An echocardiogram last year showed mild left atrial dilation and left ventricular hypertrophy. The patient's medications include lisinopril and hydrochlorothiazide. Blood pressure is 170/90 mm Hg. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?

A 32-year-old woman comes to the office with several days of tingling and numbness in both hands. She has had occasional headaches, dizziness, fatigue, poor sleep, and blurry vision. She has had no fevers, weight loss, or anorexia. Her medical history is unremarkable. The patient drinks 1 or 2 glasses of wine occasionally but does not use tobacco or illicit drugs. Her blood pressure is 132/70 mm Hg and pulse is 78/min. Sensation to light touch and pain is decreased distally in the bilateral upper extremities. Muscle strength is 5/5 in the upper and lower extremities and deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: MRI of the brain and spine

questions.correct_answer: D. MRI of the brain and spine
questions.explanation: Ans. D. MRI of the brain and spine

questions.text: 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department for exertional dyspnea, abdominal distention, and abdominal discomfort. He has a history of alcohol abuse, peptic ulcer disease, and acute pancreatitis. Physical examination shows a distended abdomen with shifting dullness and 1+ ankle edema. A diagnostic paracentesis is performed and shows the following: Albumin-2.5 g/dL Neutrophils-200/uL Blood studies show the following: Albumin-3.8 g/dL Glucose-120 mg/dL Aspartate aminotransferase-50 units/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)-40 units/L Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's ascites?
questions.correct_answer: B. Increased hepatic capillary hydrostatic pressure
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Increased hepatic capillary hydrostatic pressure

questions.text: 23-year-old man comes to the emergency department due to severe epigastric pain, nausea and vomiting after a party. He recalls a similar but less severe episode one year ago. He is a graduate student. BMI is 32 kg/m2. Physical examination reveals yellowish streaks on his palms. Blood samples appear milky and opalescent. Which of the following medications is most likely to be effective at preventing future episodes of abdominal pain in this patient?

35-year-old woman comes to the OPD for a routine physical examination. The patient reports occasional palpitations but has no other chronic medical problems. She has caries of right upper molar tooth and is due to have an extraction next week. She has no significant medical history but had been told that she has "a murmur." The patient's only medication is a daily oral contraceptive. She lives a sedentary lifestyle and reports no dyspnea on routine activity. She developed hives with use of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole in the past. Blood pressure is 120/70 mm Hg and pulse is 70/min. Physical examination shows no jugular venous distension in the upright position. Normal vesicular breath sounds are heard on chest auscultation. A late systolic murmur heard over the apex prolongs with the Valsalva manoeuvre. Which of the following is recommended for this patient prior to the procedure?
Thrombolysis can be considered in all these conditions, except?
questions.correct_answer: B. Blood pressure of more than 185/110mmHg
questions.explanation: Ans. B. Blood pressure of more than 185/110mmHg

questions.text: 4-month-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother due to concerns of appearing pale. Over the past few days, he has been sleeping more than usual and is less interactive. He continues to have good urine output. The patient was born at 40 weeks gestation and had a normal nursery course. However, the patient's newborn screen revealed an extra band representing gamma tetramers on haemoglobin electrophoresis. The patient takes a vitamin D supplement daily. Vital signs are normal. He appears tired and has mild scleral icterus. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. What is the likely diagnosis?

36-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband due to 2 days of confusion and agitation. He reports that last night she did not sleep at all and was constantly wandering around the house. He also noticed twitching of her right arm this morning. On physical examination, temperature is 38.1 C (100.7 F) blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min. She is not oriented to time or place. Her neck is supple. There are no skin or joint abnormalities. Electroencephalogram shows prominent high- amplitude slow waves over the left temporal and frontal lobes. Which is the likely CSF findings?
Which of the following drugs reversibly binds the site A?

A 35-year-old previously healthy man has noticed blood in his urine for the past 2 days Laboratory findings show a serum urea nitrogen level of 45 mg/dL and creatinine level of 3.1 mg/dL. A renal biopsy specimen is obtained; the immunofluorescence pattern of staining with antibody against human IgG is shown in the figure. Which of the following serologic findings is most likely to be present in this patient?
Match the following:
A patient was brought to the hospital after a road traffic accident. He had severe muscle injury. ECG is shown here. What change will happen to the resting membrane potential in this patient?

options.label: D
options.text: First becomes more positive, then negative

questions.text: An 11-year-old child diagnosed with acute rheumatic fever and having no valvular pathology comes to your clinic. What is the duration of prophylaxis given to this child?

52-year-old woman presents with a history of cold-induced color changes in her fingers, tight and shiny skin on her face and fingers, and small dilated blood vessels visible on her face. She also mentions difficulty in making certain facial expressions due to skin tightness. ANA staining pattern of the patient is shown in the image below.

A 63-year-old male with diabetes on a oral hypoglycaemic agent presents to the OPD with complaints of recurring instances of sinusitis and a sore throat. His fasting blood glucose level is 96 mg/dL. What is the likely drug he is on?

An experiment is being conducted on a dog blood pressure to study the effect of acetylcholine. The blood pressure is recorded at each intervention and is shown below. What does phase 4 in the graph indicate?

7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic for a routine health maintenance examination. He underwent a splenectomy a year ago for persistent anemia and jaundice. He has received the pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccinations and takes penicillin prophylaxis. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing child. The sclerae are anicteric. The abdomen is soft and nontender; no masses are palpable. Several well-healed laparoscopy scars are noted. Complete blood count is as follows: Hemoglobin: 11.3 g/dL Reticulocytes: 3% Platelets: 160,000/mm³ Leukocytes: 8,200/mm³ Peripheral blood smear with Wright stain is shown. This patient's findings are most likely related to which of the following?

options.label: B
options.text: Inability to produce beta globin chains

options.label: D
options.text: Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.correct_answer: D. Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Persistence of red blood cell precursor nuclei

questions.text: Identify the true statements: Rectal temperature is ideal for measuring the core body temperature and is higher than axillary and oral temperature readings. Hypocalcemia, hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia are complications of massive blood transfusion Aortic regurgitation murmur is noted during isovolumetric contraction Dyspnea on using the washroom is NYHA grade 3
Organize the listed bands within the sarcomere, starting from the periphery and moving towards the center. Z line M line A band H zone
Match the following images associated with GI polyps with the likely diagnosis:

52-year-old woman with known liver cirrhosis comes to the emergency department with bright bleeding per rectum for 2 days. She also has increasing abdominal distension and discomfort. The patient has been on daily furosemide and spironolactone as well as water and sodium restriction. She had variceal banding after an episode of esophageal bleeding due to esophageal varices 3 months ago. There is 2+ peripheral pitting edema. Laboratory results as follows: Hemoglobin: 8.2 g/dL Leukocytes: 4,200/mm3 Blood urea nitrogen: 72 mg/dL Serum creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL Urine sodium: 9meq/l (N-20-220meq/l) No urinary casts Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's acute kidney injury?

A patient presents with sensory loss and weakness of limbs for 3 months. He has angular stomatitis. On examination, there is loss of proprioception, vibration sensations, UMN type of lower limb weakness, absent ankle reflex. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: D. Subacute combined degeneration of cord
questions.explanation: Ans. D. Subacute combined degeneration of cord

questions.text: Identify the true statements about IBD: Smoking and appendicectomy decrease the risk of UC NOD2 and PTPN22 genes are implicated in the pathophysiology of CD Uveitis, peripheral arthritis, EN are more common with UC while PSC is more common with CD Rectal involvement with continuous disease and crypt abscess is associated with UC
Match the following:

Identify the true statements In amyloidosis, Beta pleated sheet will be seen in X-ray crystallography. There is decrease in thyroid-binding globulin, transferrin, and fibrinogen in nephrotic syndrome. Blood transfusion requires screening of donor blood for HIV, HCV, HBV but not dengue. Massive splenomegaly is noted in hairy cell leukaemia, CML and aplastic anemia.

A 53-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after she collapsed suddenly while standing and lost consciousness for approximately 3 minutes. She recovered spontaneously but was very weak and dyspneic. She also reports left-sided chest pain. The patient was recently diagnosed with colon cancer on a routine colonoscopy and is scheduled to undergo surgical resection. Her blood pressure is 86/50 mm Hg and pulse is 120/min and regular. Pulse oximetry shows 80% on room air. She is diaphoretic and tachypneic. Jugular venous pressure is 13 cm HO. Lungs are clear to auscultation. Further workup in this patient would most likely show which of the following?

options.label: D
options.text: Filling defect in PA on CTPA

questions.explanation: Ans. D. Filling defect in PA on CTPA

questions.text: 54-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to several hours of severe epigastric abdominal pain radiating to her back. She has also had nausea and several episodes of vomiting. The patient has a history of occasional upper abdominal pain after eating but has never had such severe symptoms. She has no other medical issues and takes no medications. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.6°F), blood pressure is 110/66 mm Hg, pulse is 118/min, and respirations are 24/min. The patient appears to be in moderate distress. Mucous membranes are dry. The abdomen is distended with marked epigastric tenderness. Bowel sounds are decreased. Laboratory results are as follows: Hematocrit: 48% Leukocytes: 18,800/mm³ Total bilirubin: 2.2 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase: 370 U/L Lipase: 2,192 U/L Which of the following sets of renal findings are most expected in this patient?
Which of the following conditions is associated with Hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?

18-month-old boy is brought to the emergency department due to blood in his stool, which the parents noticed when changing his diaper. The infant has had no previous bleeding and has been eating and drinking normally. He has a history of recurrent otitis media, frequent herpes labialis, and 2 episodes of pneumonia. On examination, the patient is well developed, well nourished, and has a fair complexion. He has eczema on his cheeks, trunk, and extremities. Scattered petechiae are also visible on his lower extremities. Laboratory studies show a platelet count of 24,000/mm³ and a leukocyte count of 9,000/mm³. Peripheral smear confirms the low platelet count and that the platelets are small. Genetic testing confirms the diagnosis. Which of the following processes is most likely affected by this patient's gene mutation?

45-year-old man comes to the clinic for evaluation of chronic diarrhea. He has lost almost 7 kg over the past year. He has no blood in the stool. A 24-hour stool collection shows fecal fat content of 10 g/day (normal <6 g/day). Stool microscopy shows no pathogens and no leukocytes. Serum electrolytes and renal function are within normal limits. The patient is given 25 g oral D-xylose solution, and his urinary excretion of D-xylose at 5 hours is 1.2 g (normal 4.5-7.5 g). After 4 weeks of treatment with rifaximin, the D-xylose test is repeated, and the urinary excretion at 5 hours is 1.3 g. Based on these findings, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
Match the following Acute Hep B Chronic Hep B Precore mutant Inactive carrier Coinfection Superinfection Window period Vaccination

67-year-old man comes to the emergency department with light-headedness and generalized weakness for the last 2 days. He has chronic stable angina with exertion. However, over the last 2 days he has also had occasional chest discomfort at rest. The patient's medical problems include hypertension and bronchial asthma. He has no shortness of breath, cough, or peripheral edema. His only medications are aspirin and isosorbide dinitrate. Blood pressure is 105/66 mm Hg. Electrocardiogram obtained in the emergency department is shown here. Which of the following is the best next step in management of this patient?
A woman presenting with symptoms of urinary tract infection was prescribed a drug that causes tendon rupture and arthropathy. What is the mechanism of action of the drug?

70-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department due to sudden onset of right-sided weakness and urinary incontinence that began about 10 hours ago. He has had type 2 diabetes for the last 20 years and hypertension for the last 28 years. On examination, there is 4/5 strength in the right upper extremity, 1/5 strength in the right lower extremity, and a Babinski sign on the right side. Sensation is decreased throughout the right foot and leg. Visual fields are full of no deficits. Which of the following is the most likely?
questions.correct_answer: A. Left Anterior cerebral artery stroke.
questions.explanation: Ans. A. Left Anterior cerebral artery stroke

questions.text: Match the following: Preferred site for DBS for tremor reduction Hemiballismus results from a lesion at this site Chorea results from a lesion at this site Athetosis is a result of a lesion at this site Parkinsonism occurs due to defect here
Which of the following organs can differentiate between the action of epinephrine and nor-epinephrine:
Match the following images with the diagnosis:

A 5-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother d due to leg pain. One week ago mother saw the patient fall onto the living room floor after climbing on a couch. Since the incident, she has had persistent leg pain that appears to be worse at night, and for the last 2 days she has been refusing to walk asking her mother to carry her. The patient has no chronic medical conditions but has had a mild, non-productive cough for the past month. Temperature is 38.3 C (100.9 F); all other vital signs are normal. Examination shows a pale child. The abdomen is nontender and moderate hepatosplenomegaly is noted. Palpation of the bilateral anterior proximal tibias elicits pain. There are a few scattered bruises across the chest and back. Complete blood count results are as follows: Hemoglobin-8g/dL Platelets-30,000/mm³ Leukocytes-3,000/mm³ Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

38-year-old hospitalized woman is evaluated for new-onset confusion. The patient has a prolonged history of Crohn disease and was admitted 2 days ago due to worsening abdominal pain, nausea, and watery diarrhea. She tested positive for Clostridium difficile infection and is receiving oral vancomycin and intravenous fluids. Her gastrointestinal symptoms have been improving, but since yesterday the patient has been incoherent, disoriented, and unsteady. She has no other medical conditions but has had small bowel resections due to stricture and fistula in the past and has lost 10 kg (22 lbs) over the past 6 months. On examination, she is not oriented to time or place. Pupils are equal and reactive to light. Abduction of the right eye is limited and elicits bilateral horizontal nystagmus. Motor strength and deep tendon reflexes are normal throughout. Finger-to-nose and heel-to-shin testing are normal, but the gait is wide based. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's neurologic symptoms?

65-year-old woman comes to the office for evaluation of progressively worsening memory. The patient lives alone and considers herself "very independent"; however, she has recently forgotten to pay her bills on several occasions and lost her way while driving in a previously familiar neighbourhood 2 weeks ago. Review of systems reveals no other symptoms except for mild urinary urgency. The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. The lungs are clear to auscultation, and a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is present. The cranial nerves are intact, fundoscopy is normal, and there is no tremor. The patient immediately recalls all 3 of 3 items read to her, but 5 minutes later she can’t remember none of them. Her gait is broad-based and shuffling. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's symptoms?

Which of the following is not true about nitric oxide? eNOS is constitutively expressed and helps regulate vascular tone. NO helps in generation of free radicals in neutrophil at the time of inflammation Interferon-γ (IFN-γ) or microbial products can activate inducible NOS. Synthesis of NO requires NOS action on arginine.
Match the following case scenarios with the likely diagnosis:
Identify the schedule of the following drug based on the image:

66-year-old woman comes to the office due to bloating, flatulence, and abdominal discomfort for the past 6 months. The patient has mild, intermittent, crampy abdominal pain that is unrelated to eating and does not improve after defecation. She also has 2 or 3 loose, watery bowel movements daily. The patient has had no hematochezia, melena, vomiting, or unexpected weight loss. Medical history is significant for degenerative disk disease, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. Medications include insulin, amlodipine, and oxycodone. Faecal occult blood test is negative. Complete blood count is normal. Serum creatinine is 1.9 mg/dL and hemoglobin A1c is 9.3%. Carbohydrate breath testing using glucose is abnormal. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for this patient?
Match the following images with the respective named appearances:
The drugs X and Y have equal:

options.label: A
options.text: Effectiveness of drug in life threatening conditions

options.label: B
options.text: The maximal intensity of response that can be produced by the drug

options.label: C
options.text: The dose of the drug needed to produce half-maximal effect

options.label: D
options.text: The minimum dose of the drug needed to produce toxic effect

questions.correct_answer: B. The maximal intensity of response that can be produced by the drug
questions.explanation: Ans. B. The maximal intensity of response that can be produced by the drug

questions.text: A woman came in with complaints of excessive daytime sleepiness and difficulties in concentration and memory persisting for a year. During the examination, her Body Mass Index (BMI) was measured at 43 kg/m2, and her blood pressure (BP) was recorded as 170/98 mmHg. Arterial Blood Gas (ABG) analysis was performed while she was awake, and the results are as follows. Based on the provided information, what is the probable diagnosis? PaO 2 – 70 mmHg PaCO 2 – 53 mmHg HCO 3 - - 33 mmHg

Identify the true statements about treatment and prophylaxis in HIV-AIDS: Viral load monitoring is best used to monitor treatment efficacy In presence of HIV-TB coinfection patient should be initially treated with ATT followed by ART to prevent risk of IRIS ART should be initiated within 2 weeks of TB treatment if CD4 <50/mm3 except TB meningitis where it is initiated after 8 weeks For prophylaxis against opportunistic infections, start cotrimoxazole when CD4 <200, fluconazole when CD4<100, and azithromycin if CD4<50.
Name the drug that acts on both the marked points.
